text: @LindaHirshman1 @ebruenig Would you say that Medicare for All encourages women to have children because it socializes the cost of health care for kids? In the status quo system, having a kid can cause your health care premiums to go up by a lot. So by your reasoning, socializing that is anti-woman right?

@LindaHirshman1 @ebruenig For example, would you say providing free public schooling encourages women to have children because, in the absence of it, people would have fewer children because of the cost of school?

@LindaHirshman1 @ebruenig Socializing the cost of children as opposed to individualizing the cost by requiring people to cover it with their factor payments will result in different decisions being made. Does the former encourage or the latter discourage? What's the default mode of society?
@LindaHirshman1 i wouldn't say money is a particularly good measure of any person's "main value"

@ebruenig I'm good with the future oriented and racially redistributive effects of the child allowance. But it's never paired with what's good for women. Could that be because women's main value is in making babies?
@LindaHirshman1 let's do all this + permanent child allowance
